data.boilerplate:
### 🚀 Let's launch your Innovation Challenge!

1. Register on the website
2. Check tourismdata.ch for data sources
3. Use our ChatGPT enhanced tool

Write a **Title** and short **Summary**, select a **Template** if one is available, or use the **Readme** link to fetch content from a [supported open repository](https://docs.dribdat.cc/sync). Need more help? Get in touch with the [organising team](/about), or raise [an issue](https://github.com/dribdat/dribdat/issues).
data.community_embed:
This website was created as part of Resilient Tourism Project (Subproject 1: National Data Infrastructure for Tourism) - one of 15 flagship projects approved and supported by Innosuisse - the Swiss Innovation Agency. Flagship projects are systemic and transdisciplinary innovations that are central to current and future economic and social challenges in Switzerland.

The contents of this website, unless otherwise stated, are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. The application that powers this site is available under the MIT license.


All attendees, sponsors, partners, volunteers and staff at our hackathon are required to agree with the Hack Code of Conduct. Organisers will enforce this code throughout the event. We expect cooperation from all participants to ensure a safe environment for everybody.
data.description: We are pleased to announce the **Innovation and Mapping Festival 2025** – a unique event to mark the signing of the [Non-Personal Data Standardization Charter](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/project/22): _We, the members of the RDTC, together with IT service providers, have decided to create a Mastermapping for non-personal but marketing-relevant data that is relevant for tourists in Switzerland. The basis for mapping data is a common, standardised categorization of data. The purpose is to simplify the exchange of data between systems and increase efficiency when mapping data._ Read the [full text](https://www.tourismdata.ch/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/Charta_Version_Website.pdf) of the Charter, and find out more on [tourismdata.ch](https://tourismdata.ch).
data.instruction:
# Information for participants

This online innovation workspace has been developed for the [Resilient Tourism](https://www.resilienttourism.ch/) project based on **[Dribdat](https://dribdat.cc)**. On each page we have linked to optional tools, such as [Excalidraw](https://github.com/excalidraw), which are recommended for digital ideation sprints. Once you join a challenge, you can work as a team using any tool. Make progress through a series of [workshop stages](/event/2/resources) by regularly **Posting updates** with sketches, screenshots or comments.

#### If you have any questions, please reach out the event organizers: [✉️ Sandro](mailto:sandro.suter@hslu.ch) or [✉️ Anna](mailto:anna.para@hslu.ch)

<br clear="all">


## Pre-event

After the Challenge Pitch on February 4, the list of preferred challenges will be published. You can choose which challenge(s) you are interested in. Taking your priorities into consideration, the organizers will build a diverse **4-6 people team** for each challenge that you see above. Until the main event on March 14, you are invited to already think what ideas you already have as well as what skills you can contribute. You can already reflect on potential solutions to the presented challenges and what resources would be needed to solve the problem. The more you have already thought about the challenges the faster you and your team can get your hands at work.

## Digital ideation

To facilitate the event and the challenges, we are using several web applications - the one you are looking at now is [Dribdat](https://dribdat.cc): a playful ideation and open source challenge board to help organize co-creative sessions. This platform helps teams to sustain and to document their efforts, streamlining things for the organising team. We have pre-configured each challenge with an [Excalidraw](https://github.com/excalidraw) canvas and a [Systemic Design Framework](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/project/21) template. You can find this and further materials in the **[Resource area](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/event/2/resources)**.

## If you're stuck

Check out the [Help area & Handbook](/about) to get an understanding of the platform and how it is used for hackathons all around [Switzerland](https://dribdat.cc/tour). You can also take part in our Q&A Calls, that are organized on **17th February** and on **10th March** at 15.00. During the calls we will show you how to work with our platforms and try to answer all your questions. Participation is not compulsory. We will of course, also have staff and helpers on location during the event to help you out!

## What to bring

To attend the Festival in Zurich on March 14, we mostly need you to show up with plenty of motivation and in a good mood to hack tourism challenges! You will be successful if you are open-minded and are ready to tackle the tasks within a team. To actively work on the challenges, you should bring a laptop - please don't forget your charging cable `;)`

## At the event

The event in Zurich starts with a welcoming Coffee and Get together. After that the teams for the challenges will start working together. The goal of the Innovation and Mapping Festival is to create a first prototype for the challenge. Depending on the challenge you will solve it by preparing a conceptual solution, but you can also program an algorithm - the most important thing is to solve your challenge in a creative and multidisciplinary way.
data.name: Innovation and Mapping Festival

data.autotext:
# Door2track

This project was generated with [Angular CLI](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli) version 17.0.10.

## Development server

Run `ng serve` for a dev server. Navigate to `http://localhost:4200/`. The application will automatically reload if you change any of the source files.

## Code scaffolding

Run `ng generate component component-name` to generate a new component. You can also use `ng generate directive|pipe|service|class|guard|interface|enum|module`.

## Build

Run `ng build` to build the project. The build artifacts will be stored in the `dist/` directory.

## Running unit tests

Run `ng test` to execute the unit tests via [Karma](https://karma-runner.github.io).

## Running end-to-end tests

Run `ng e2e` to execute the end-to-end tests via a platform of your choice. To use this command, you need to first add a package that implements end-to-end testing capabilities.

## Further help

To get more help on the Angular CLI use `ng help` or go check out the [Angular CLI Overview and Command Reference](https://angular.io/cli) page.
data.excerpt:
The goal of this challenge is to design and develop a tool that allows users to optimize their available time by suggesting personalized cross-country skiing opportunities. The tool should allow users to enter the time they have available and in return suggest customized recommendations for cross-country skiing trails that fit within that time frame.
To ensure practicality and accuracy, the tool must take into account essential factors such as travel time (calculated using public transport and ...
data.longtext:
The goal of this challenge is to design and develop a tool that allows users to optimize their available time by suggesting personalized cross-country skiing opportunities. The tool should allow users to enter the time they have available and in return suggest customized recommendations for cross-country skiing trails that fit within that time frame.
To ensure practicality and accuracy, the tool must take into account essential factors such as travel time (calculated using public transport and walking route), the status of the trail and the duration of the selected activities. This requires a seamless integration of data from different sources to make meaningful and actionable suggestions.
The ultimate goal is to create a solution that not only respects users’ schedules, but also enhances their experience by making the most of the moments available, be it for leisure, learning or personal growth.

## Main Tasks

* Development of a standardized data model to combine the three main data sources (Open Journey Planner, SISAG API, Openstreet Map)
* Creation of a user-friendly interface for the tool
* Attractive visualization of the results of the tool

## Resources

- [Whiteboard - Excalidraw](https://link.excalidraw.com/l/71IEdlODkrp/xKTMX331Ji)
- https://s3.dribdat.cc/tourism/imf/36/WYB7G/oj.csv

## SisControl
- Sisag Demo Data https://staging-export.siscontrol.ch/sismedia/json/8927FB40-50DA-4BAF-B085-EDCFE671BCFA
- Sisag Json Doku https://prodsiscontrolpublic.blob.core.windows.net/public-assets/doc/SisMediaJsonExportDocumentation.html

## API Open Journey Planner

- [Open Journey Planner (OJP) Version 2.0](https://data.opentransportdata.swiss/en/dataset/ojp2-0)
- API: https://api.opentransportdata.swiss/ojp20
- [How to get an API Key](https://opentransportdata.swiss/en/howto-access-apis/)
- [OJP 2.0 Demo App](https://tools.odpch.ch/ojp-demo-v2/search)
- [Documentation "TripRequest"](https://opentransportdata.swiss/en/cookbook/ojptriprequest/)
- [OpenAPI/Swagger](https://opentdatach.github.io/api-explorer2/#/default/OJP2.0)

## OpenStreetMap data
Visualisation of OSM data for cross-country tracks in Andermatt:
- [OpenSnowMap](https://www.opensnowmap.org/#map=15/8.588/46.628&b=snowmap&m=false&h=false) 
- [OpenSkiMap](https://openskimap.org/?obj=3792d0c81f0d96b133b6cec1e471b9ae4d1d39f3#14.38/46.629/8.59237)[

## Source code
- [frontend](https://github.com/Marc-I/door-2-track-planner-frontend)
- [backend](https://github.com/decaillet/door-2-track-planner-backend)
data.name: Door2Track Planner
data.team: AndrA, Michael, decaillet, thomas, marc, mth, mhandschuh, michaelfux

data.excerpt: Climate change poses significant challenges for tourist destinations. Extreme weather conditions, such as heatwaves, heavy rainfall, or lack of snow, often render existing offerings less appealing or difficult to access. At the same time, there is a growing demand for nature-based experiences that are not only more sustainable but also adaptable to various climatic conditions. However, many destinations remain heavily reliant on specific weather patterns, creating a lack of flexible and future-p...
data.longtext:
Climate change poses significant challenges for tourist destinations. Extreme weather conditions, such as heatwaves, heavy rainfall, or lack of snow, often render existing offerings less appealing or difficult to access. At the same time, there is a growing demand for nature-based experiences that are not only more sustainable but also adaptable to various climatic conditions. However, many destinations remain heavily reliant on specific weather patterns, creating a lack of flexible and future-proof alternatives.

**“Which sustainable tourism offerings can we (further) develop to adapt flexibly to climatic changes and varying weather conditions?“**

### Main Tasks

- Design and/or further develop touristic offerings: Create experiences that, where relevant, strengthen the connection to nature and remain attractive across diverse weather conditions.
- Promote sustainability: Design concepts that prioritize both ecological and social sustainability.
- Adapt to climatic changes: Design or further develop offerings that can adjust to shifting climatic conditions.
- Raise climate awareness: Foster guests’ understanding of climate change impacts and the importance of sustainable travel.

## Resources

- [Whiteboard - Excalidraw](https://link.excalidraw.com/l/71IEdlODkrp/9TLUug28vgq)
- [Challenge - Presentation](https://www.tourismdata.ch/events/innovation-and-mapping-festival/challenges/climate-resilience-in-tourism/)
- [Further resources ...](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/event/2/resources)
data.name: Climate Resilience in Tourism
data.team: anjamueller, ClaudioSimoni, Laure, SindyK, LisaW, EricTerrabiom, OdileRoulet

data.excerpt:
#### Innovating Tourism for the late autumn period for the destinations of Crans-Montana and Anniviers

This challenge invites teams to harness the power of **non-personal data** from the Crans-Montana and Anniviers regions to create **innovative strategies** that boost tourism in the autumn season. Participants will analyze diverse datasets, including:

* **Booking patterns** for accommodations and activities.
* **Visitor origins and seasonality trends** from Swisscom data.
* **Website tr...
data.longtext:
#### Innovating Tourism for the late autumn period for the destinations of Crans-Montana and Anniviers

This challenge invites teams to harness the power of **non-personal data** from the Crans-Montana and Anniviers regions to create **innovative strategies** that boost tourism in the autumn season. Participants will analyze diverse datasets, including:

* **Booking patterns** for accommodations and activities.
* **Visitor origins and seasonality trends** from Swisscom data.
* **Website traffic and search behavior** specific to autumn.
* **Transport data** revealing travel dynamics and seasonality.
* Historical and real-time insights provided by our destination partners and the **regional tourism observatory Tourobs** ([www.tourobs.ch](http://www.tourobs.ch/)).

**Your mission:** Uncover the untapped opportunities of the late-autumn season and co-create the future of tourism!

## Main Tasks

Teams will tackle questions such as:

* How can we better understand and meet the needs of autumn visitors?
* What gaps exist in the current tourism offering, and how can they be filled?
* How can digital tools (e.g., interactive maps or dashboards) enhance decision-making for both tourists and local stakeholders?

The goal is to translate data insights into actionable solutions that could include new products, marketing strategies, or tools designed to extend the tourist season and maximize regional potential.

## Resources

- [Whiteboard - Excalidraw](https://link.excalidraw.com/l/71IEdlODkrp/1TjcHFQmxNc)
- [Data share - Switch Drive](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/project/23)
- [Challenge - Presentation](https://www.tourismdata.ch/events/innovation-and-mapping-festival/challenges/unlocking-autumn/)
- [Further Resources ...](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/event/2/resources)

---

# **1\. Context and Challenge**

### **The Problem:**

Autumn in the Alps, particularly in **Crans-Montana and Anniviers**, is an **untapped tourism season**. While winter and summer attract high visitor numbers, late autumn sees **low tourism activity**, with many businesses closing and limited structured offers for visitors.

### **Why It Matters:**

* **Economic Potential**: Businesses struggle to remain open due to uncertain demand, leading to revenue loss.
* **Visitor Experience**: Tourists often lack information on **what is open**, limiting their stay and reducing repeat visits.
* **Climate Sensitivity**: Autumn tourism is highly **weather-dependent**, requiring better planning to counter fluctuating conditions.

### **The Hackathon Challenge**

Participants will **analyze tourism data** to develop **data-driven strategies** that extend the **late-autumn season** by improving:

* **Tourist engagement** through better marketing and experience design.
* **Business coordination** to ensure **accommodation, activities, and restaurants** remain open.
* **Sustainability** by leveraging **local events, nature, and gastronomy** to attract off-season visitors.

***

## **2\. Key Objectives for Hackathon Participants**

1. **Understanding Visitor Demand:**
    * Identify who visits in autumn and what they seek (e.g., hiking, photography, wine tastings).
    * Analyze **past booking patterns**, **visitor origins**, and **website traffic trends**.
    * Evaluate **weather patterns** and their influence on visitor flow.
2. **Filling Gaps in the Tourism Offer:**
    * **Mapping tourism availability**: What’s open? What’s missing? What should be coordinated?
    * Propose **business synergies** that enable cost-effective operations in the shoulder season.
3. **Creating Digital Tools for Decision-Making:**
    * Develop **interactive maps** showing **real-time open locations, activities, and accommodations**.
    * Design **regional collaboration dashboards** for tourism providers to align offers.
4. **Marketing & Promotion Strategies:**
    * Define **target audience segmentation** (e.g., adventure tourists, remote workers, cultural tourists).
    * Propose **digital marketing and seasonal branding strategies** (social media campaigns, influencer partnerships, event packages).

***

## **3\. Possible Solution Strategies**

### **A. Experience & Product Development**

* **Gastronomy & Local Culture:** Promote **culinary experiences** (game meat, alpine cheeses, autumn wine tastings, guided food trails).
* **Outdoor Adventures:** Design and promote **season-specific activities**, such as:
    * **Guided hikes** through golden larch forests.
    * **Wildlife observation** (e.g., red deer rut).
    * **Photography and nature retreats**.
* **Event-Based Tourism:** Identify key **regional events** (festivals, markets) and integrate them into travel offers.
* **Wellness & Remote Work Offers:** Develop **autumn wellness retreats** or "workation" packages for digital nomads.

### **B. Enhancing Business Coordination**

* **Tourism Availability Dashboard**: A tool for businesses to share **opening hours, available offers, and coordinate seasonal packages**.
* **Multi-Destination Cooperation**: Link attractions across **30-50km radius** to create combined regional offers.
* **Low-Cost Activity Expansion**: Introduce **affordable off-season activities** (e.g., guided heritage walks, mobile self-guided tours).

### **C. Smart Data & Digital Solutions**

* **Real-Time Interactive Maps**: Show what’s open, where to go, and live availability.
* **Predictive Models for Demand**: Using past booking and visitor flow data to forecast autumn demand.
* **Weather-Responsive Offers**: Provide **alternative activity suggestions** in case of bad weather.

## **4\. Description of Provided Data**

The following datasets are available for the **Automne Insights Hackathon**, covering **tourism demand, visitor behavior, weather impact, events, and business availability** in Crans-Montana and Anniviers.

1. **Overnight statistics (HESTA, Para)**
    * Monthly data since 2015 for hotels (demand and suuply)
    * [Open data from Bfs/Ofs](https://www.pxweb.bfs.admin.ch/pxweb/de/px-x-1003020000_101/px-x-1003020000_101/px-x-1003020000_101.px)
    * Parahotellerie: monthly data on overnights and booking windows for different source markets
2. **Vacation Calendar (2025)**
    * Contains **school holiday periods** for different regions, allowing teams to **identify peak opportunities for autumn promotions**.
3. **Event Data (Guidle Export)**
    * Details **cultural, sporting, and gastronomic events** available in the region.
    * Includes event **dates, descriptions, categories, ticketing, and locations**.
    * Helps in understanding **which events drive tourism interest in autumn**.
4. **Weather Data (Montana & Mottec-Zinal)**
    * Daily weather records for **2023-2024**, including:
        * **Temperature variations**
        * **Precipitation**
        * **Sunshine duration**
    * Useful for **correlating weather patterns with visitor trends** and **forecasting weather-sensitive demand**.
5. **Traffic & Digital Analytics (Swisscom, Google Analytics)**
    * Includes **visitor movement data**, web traffic from DMO websites, and booking platform insights.
    * Helps to analyze:
        * **Booking behavior**
        * **Online search trends for autumn activities**
        * **Mobile network-based tourist presence data**.
6. **Points of Interest (POIs) in Valais Central**
    * Geolocation data of **attractions, accommodations, restaurants, and activities**.
    * Essential for mapping **business availability** and aligning **real-time tourism offerings**.
    * 

***

### **Data Resources Available**

Teams will work with a **diverse set of datasets** to develop solutions that extend the **autumn tourism season**.

| **Dataset** | **What It Covers** | **Potential Use in Hackathon** |
| ------- | -------------- | -------------------------- |
| **Vacation Calendar** | School holidays for 2025 | Identify peaks in **family travel demand** for autumn tourism. |
| **Event Data (Guidle)** | Event schedules, descriptions, locations | Promote **autumn events** as key drivers for visitation. |
| **Weather Data** | Daily temp., precipitation, sunshine (2023-2024) | Study **weather impact** on visitor behavior and optimize weather-adaptive strategies. |
| **Traffic & Digital Analytics** | Booking patterns, online search behavior, visitor mobility | Detect **seasonality trends** and adjust tourism marketing. |
| **POIs in Valais Central** | Hotels, restaurants, attractions | Develop **interactive maps** of real-time business availability. |

***

These datasets will enable teams to:

* **Predict visitor demand** and **business feasibility** for extending the season.
* **Build digital tools** (interactive maps, dashboards) for stakeholders.
* **Optimize marketing efforts** based on **search behavior and weather trends**.
data.name: Unlocking Autumn
data.summary: Data-Driven Strategies to Expand Tourism into October and November
data.team: RolandSchegg, LauraSidler, moreno, AmlieKeller, Ashan, Denise, MarianaContreras, Katharina, Ronald

data.excerpt:
Not all places are accessible to everyone. To effectively plan travel, accommodations, or social
outings, individuals with diverse disabilities require readily available information about the accessibility of locations. Sitios has established a platform for collecting and sharing such crucial
data. It encompasses a comprehensive set of criteria for evaluating building accessibility tailored to the specific needs of various disabilities. However, manually gathering this information
is a labori...
data.longtext:
Not all places are accessible to everyone. To effectively plan travel, accommodations, or social
outings, individuals with diverse disabilities require readily available information about the accessibility of locations. Sitios has established a platform for collecting and sharing such crucial
data. It encompasses a comprehensive set of criteria for evaluating building accessibility tailored to the specific needs of various disabilities. However, manually gathering this information
is a laborious and time-consuming process. Recognizing the transformative potential of artificial
intelligence (AI), we challenge you to find existing solutions that can autonomously extract relevant accessibility information directly from images of buildings and their immediate surroundings.

## Tasks

* Find AI tools capable of analyzing images of building interiors and exteriors to identify key accessibility features.
* Use these AI tools to detect and classify common accessibility features such as ramps, stairs, elevators, doorways, restrooms, and signage.
* Evaluate the AI tools and extracted information in terms of accuracy and completeness, ease of use, robustness and generalizability across different building types and image conditions.

With this GraphQL query the images are obtained from the [Ginto API](https://www.sitios.info/en/support/doc/access-api) for a 1km radius around our location:

```graphql
query EntriesBySearch {
    entriesBySearch(within: 1, lat: 47.37087, lng: 8.52935) {
        nodes {
            entryId
            name
            mainImage {
                url(imageSize: MEDIUM)
            }
        }
    }
}
```

(the results are in the `32pictures.csv` file on our data share)

## Resources

![QGPG3IH2.jpg](https://s3.dribdat.cc/tourism/imf/1/KE2ID/QGPG3IH2.jpg)

* [Whiteboard - Excalidraw](https://link.excalidraw.com/l/71IEdlODkrp/7Cno7Rpa2P1)
* [Data share - Switch Drive](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/project/23)
* [Challenge - Presentation](https://www.tourismdata.ch/events/innovation-and-mapping-festival/challenges/ai-for-accessibility/)
* [Further resources ...](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/event/2/resources)

##### _Your building photos?_

![YPVJ4EPH.jpg](https://s3.dribdat.cc/tourism/imf/1/99Q0V/YPVJ4EPH.jpg)

Image by @[loleg](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/user/loleg) CC BY 4.0 - more [shared here](https://photos.app.goo.gl/XyXNsqRoKHSYr7ZRA) and you are welcome to add your own!

## Recommendations

Open our Jupyter notebook [in Google Colab](https://colab.research.google.com/drive/19N0clqCzmLyGcc_X6Lh350yXtSy96Qwa?usp=sharing) or download the [GitHub Gist](https://gist.github.com/loleg/5fcd33dc7500460686cff3b04fd9660c). It contains an example of how to combine the Ginto data and process it using open source Language-Vision Models that even work well on a smartphone app. Here are some sample observations from actual user photos:

![R0GKCTJX.png](https://s3.dribdat.cc/tourism/imf/1/KDCXI/R0GKCTJX.png)

Tips on how to publish an image dataset for ML projects:

- https://huggingface.co/docs/datasets/image_dataset
- https://hackernoon.com/7-steps-to-prepare-a-dataset-for-an-image-based-ai-project
data.name: AI for Accessibility
data.summary: Automation of building assessments to increase transparency for people with disabilities

data.excerpt: Nowadays most websites and apps provide a prominent search function by which users can browse through the content repository of a website. This content is usually classified in categories (e.g. event, restaurant, museum) and can contain a diverse set of attributes (e.g. child-friendly). These categories and attributes are generally referred to as tags. Tags can be helpful to offer meaningful search experiences especially when they are combined to filter/present suitable search results (e.g. all ...
data.longtext:
Nowadays most websites and apps provide a prominent search function by which users can browse through the content repository of a website. This content is usually classified in categories (e.g. event, restaurant, museum) and can contain a diverse set of attributes (e.g. child-friendly). These categories and attributes are generally referred to as tags. Tags can be helpful to offer meaningful search experiences especially when they are combined to filter/present suitable search results (e.g. all restaurants which are classified as child-friendly).

**Develop a search algorithm that understands the search intent of a user and identifies one or a combination (intersection) of multiple tags. The algorithm should already consider different tag specifications and spelling mistakes.**

## Main Tasks

* **Design a mechanism to parse and interpret user search queries to identify the underlying intent.** The algorithm should analyze keywords, contextual phrases, and synonyms to map queries to relevant tags.
* **Implement a system that normalizes tag variations by accounting for synonyms, plurals, and common spelling errors.** Ensure it can recognize similar tags across different formats (e.g., “child-friendly” vs. “kid-friendly”).
* **Create an intersection logic to combine multiple tags based on user input**, ensuring results reflect the most relevant match. Integrate a scoring system to rank search results by relevance to user intent.

## Resources

- [Whiteboard - Excalidraw](https://link.excalidraw.com/l/71IEdlODkrp/1pjYLJyxJzL)
- [Data share - Switch Drive](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/project/23)
- [Challenge - Presentation](https://www.tourismdata.ch/events/innovation-and-mapping-festival/challenges/ai-supported-tag-search/)
- [Further resources ...](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/event/2/resources)
data.name: Concept for AI supported tag search

data.excerpt:
Tourism destinations often face an uneven distribution of visitor flows, with overcrowding during peak times and underutilization in quieter periods. This imbalance not only reduces guest satisfaction during peak times but also leads to inefficient use of resources and missed economic potential in off-peak periods. There is a lack of innovative approaches to motivate travelers to visit outside peak times and to enhance the appeal of less frequented periods.

*“How can we develop innovative str...
data.longtext:
Tourism destinations often face an uneven distribution of visitor flows, with overcrowding during peak times and underutilization in quieter periods. This imbalance not only reduces guest satisfaction during peak times but also leads to inefficient use of resources and missed economic potential in off-peak periods. There is a lack of innovative approaches to motivate travelers to visit outside peak times and to enhance the appeal of less frequented periods.

*“How can we develop innovative strategies to manage visitor flows in a tourism destination and make traveling outside peak times more attractive?”*

### Main Tasks

* **Behavioral Steering:** Development of incentives or mechanisms to motivate guests to travel outside peak times (e.g., discounts, exclusive experiences).
* **Enhancing Appeal:** Ideas for new offers or experiences specifically designed for less frequented periods to improve utilization.
* **Leveraging Data and Technology:** Integration of digital tools or analytics platforms to evaluate visitor data and provide real-time information to better direct guests.
* **Communication and Marketing:** Development of targeted communication strategies that emphasize the benefits of traveling outside peak times and attract new audience segments.
* **Sustainability:** Ensuring that the developed solutions are sustainable in the long term and economically viable for all stakeholders.

## Resources

- [Whiteboard - Excalidraw](https://link.excalidraw.com/l/71IEdlODkrp/9sTuXPCo7Zp)
- [Challenge - Presentation](https://www.tourismdata.ch/events/innovation-and-mapping-festival/challenges/managing-visitor-flows/)
- [Further resources ...](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/event/2/resources)
data.name: Managing Visitor Flows

data.excerpt:
Tourism destinations face the challenge of offering sustainable and attractive mobility solutions that meet the needs of travelers while addressing local conditions. Two key issues emerge:

1. **Overcoming the “first and last mile”**, especially regarding specific mobility needs such as strollers, wheelchairs, or luggage.
2. **Developing and integrating mobility solutions** in rural areas to ensure practical and intermodal connections.

**“How can we design a sustainable and user-friendly m...
data.longtext:
Tourism destinations face the challenge of offering sustainable and attractive mobility solutions that meet the needs of travelers while addressing local conditions. Two key issues emerge:

1. **Overcoming the “first and last mile”**, especially regarding specific mobility needs such as strollers, wheelchairs, or luggage.
2. **Developing and integrating mobility solutions** in rural areas to ensure practical and intermodal connections.

**“How can we design a sustainable and user-friendly mobility solution that makes the first and last mile in a tourism destination accessible and convenient, while improving connectivity to rural areas?”**

### Main Tasks

* Develop ideas and prototypes for practical mobility solutions that address diverse user needs (e.g., accessibility, flexibility).
* Design approaches for intermodal connections in rural areas that are locally feasible and economically sustainable.

## Resources

- [Whiteboard - Excalidraw](https://link.excalidraw.com/l/71IEdlODkrp/i79KJKT4R)
- [Data share - Switch Drive](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/project/23)
- [Challenge - Presentation](https://www.tourismdata.ch/events/innovation-and-mapping-festival/challenges/futuremobilityfortourismdestinations/)
- [Further resources ...](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/event/2/resources)
data.name: Future Mobility for Tourism Destinations

data.excerpt: Lucerne Tourism wants to develop a web-based map application that will act as a digital travel guide for the Lucerne-Lake Lucerne Region. A central feature is a category-based navigation system that allows users to filter and discover places according to their interests. The challenge here is to analyze the existing category trees and simplify them in such a way that the application remains clear. At the same time, the relevant information density must not be lost. It is important to find the ri...
data.longtext:
Lucerne Tourism wants to develop a web-based map application that will act as a digital travel guide for the Lucerne-Lake Lucerne Region. A central feature is a category-based navigation system that allows users to filter and discover places according to their interests. The challenge here is to analyze the existing category trees and simplify them in such a way that the application remains clear. At the same time, the relevant information density must not be lost. It is important to find the right balance between simplicity and completeness.

## Main Tasks

* How can existing category trees be analyzed and optimized for a clearer structure?
* Which approaches can ensure that no important information is lost through simplification?
* How can the design be created in such a way that it offers an intuitive and appealing user experience?
* Which technical solutions make it possible to dynamically adapt the categories to the user’s preferences?
* The result should be a well-organized, user-friendly navigation interface that enriches the travel experience and optimally presents the diverse offerings of the Lucerne-Lake Lucerne Region.

## Resources

- [Whiteboard - Excalidraw](https://link.excalidraw.com/l/71IEdlODkrp/4Sch7U0mb6u)
- [Data share - Switch Drive](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/project/23)
- [Challenge - Presentation](https://www.tourismdata.ch/events/innovation-and-mapping-festival/challenges/mapp-app/)
- [Further resources ...](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/event/2/resources)
data.name: Map App

data.excerpt:
For a given destination, relevant data is typically managed across various specialized applications and needs to be deployed across multiple channels such as websites, apps, or chatbots. The source systems provide this data in diverse formats, types, and categories, both structured and unstructured. discover.swiss offers a system that aggregates this data and transforms it into a unified schema based on standards like Schema.org.

**Understanding, converting, mapping, and extracting data consu...
data.longtext:
For a given destination, relevant data is typically managed across various specialized applications and needs to be deployed across multiple channels such as websites, apps, or chatbots. The source systems provide this data in diverse formats, types, and categories, both structured and unstructured. discover.swiss offers a system that aggregates this data and transforms it into a unified schema based on standards like Schema.org.

**Understanding, converting, mapping, and extracting data consumes the majority of development time. By leveraging AI-assisted processes, this effort could be significantly reduced, enabling more systems to be integrated cost-effectively.**

## Main Tasks

**How can tourism-relevant data be automatically transferred from different forms into a standardized schema?** For example, setting types, categories, extracting opening hours, etc.? The solution should be more than a fixed set of rules, but it could be a system that automatically creates a mapping definition based on two data schemas that can then be used in different systems. A kind of mapping definition that can also serve as documentation of the mapping.

**Typing of data such as the recognition of an event**

**Extracting and enriching the data**, e.g:

* Extracting opening hours from free text into a structured format
* Setting kitchen styles
* Recognizing that an unstructured text, e.g. the description on a website, serves as the basis for a bar with opening hours, drinks list and associated additional events. For example, the text could contain that the bar hosts a karaoke evening every Thursday at 8 pm, which could also be extracted and typed as an event data set

**Extract the source, author and license for correct source information**

## Data

* Data from open sources that discover.swiss has already connected, e.g. Zurich Tourism CMS, Switzerland Tourism OpenData datasets, other OpenData datasets such as electric charging stations
* Example of a list of websites (restaurants, bars, museums) with descriptions
* Data already mapped for verification
* discover.swiss type, tag and category tree and data schema

## Resources

* [Whiteboard - Excalidraw](https://link.excalidraw.com/l/71IEdlODkrp/6VMvVJdj5RB)
* [Data share - Switch Drive](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/project/23) (Use for sharing data within Team - Due to licence topics the Challenge Owner will give you the data on a stick)
* [Challenge - Presentation](https://www.tourismdata.ch/events/innovation-and-mapping-festival/challenges/ai-based-data-structuring/)
* [Further resources ...](https://festival.tourismdata.ch/event/2/resources)
data.name: AI-based data structuring
data.summary: Explore the Potential of AI in modern data structuring
